title: Need help ASAP!!!
content:
It looks like Rockwell, except for the curlies!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090927093910im_/http:/typophile.com/files/onStage2009logo_3926.jpg)
author: bdunn1285

comments.content:
Thank you sooooo much, your awesomeness!!!

:-D

[Archer](http://web.archive.org/web/20090927093910/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100033).

Could you cut out the ASAP!!!-stuff, please.  
Everbody gets served around here.
I’m sorry, I’m in the middle of my workday and need to have this proofed out by 4.

Stroked? I think it’s Bold SC.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090927093910im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Bild4_3936.jpg)
You’re right; I was sloppy because I knew I had to be fast to beat your answer!

:-)

@ Barbara  
I just saw that you’re new to Typophile.  
Welcome.  
 [Please use a descriptive title next time! Thank you.](http://web.archive.org/web/20090927093910/http:/typophile.com/forum/typeid/faq/#Q_2)  
Good title would have been “onStage, slab serif with ball terminals”.

@ Jan  
‘Good title would have been “onStage, slab serif with ball terminals”.’

someone new to this forum (or serious typography in general)  
might not be au fait with the jargon…

<cite>someone new to this forum (or serious typography in general) might not be au fait with the jargon…</cite>

What can we do? Typography is just that sexy. ;-)

Regarding terminology – I think “curlies” is much cuter than “ball terminals”.  
I might just adapt that :)

The girls may call ’em curlies.  
The guys (or the cheeky) call ’em [ball terminals](http://web.archive.org/web/20090927093910/http:/typographica.org/001077.php).

But then it depends on the gender of the object too, not just the subject: I think Archer is much more “curly” than “ballsy”. I mean Archer is a girl. Miller is a guy.  
:-)

Of course Archer is a girl. The goal was to create a feminine slab serif, which is a contradiction in itself. Since the good people at H&FJ did it, it was a success nonetheless, if only by adding curlies to make sure. ;-)

<cite>“a feminine slab serif, which is a contradiction in itself”</cite>  
Interesting – do you really think so?  
In my book, “feminine” doesn’t \*need\* to mean slender, swirly, gracious and elegant.

Ooohhhh, OK. It took me a while to recognize where you’re heading.  
Say, did I see any weights other than the regular of [Ernestine](http://web.archive.org/web/20090927093910/http:/typophile.com/node/53395) yet?

_In my book, “feminine” doesn’t \*need\* to mean..._  
Maybe not in yours especially, but in general it does.  
Just search for \*feminine\* or \*girl\* at MyFonts.  
Agreed, there is certainly more to the feminine side of Archer than the \*curlies\*. But isn’t Archer such an unusual slab because it looks so... feminine?

Thanks for the elaboration! I was just curious.

<cite>“Say, did I see…”</cite>  
Soon. :-)
